questions.text:
What is the output of the following code snippet, assuming 'temp.dat' is created successfully?

try (FileOutputStream output = new FileOutputStream("temp.dat")) {
  int value = 300;
  output.write(value);
}
try (FileInputStream input = new FileInputStream("temp.dat")) {
  System.out.println(input.read());
}
questions.explanation: The write(int b) method writes only the low 8 bits of the integer. 300 in binary is 100101100. The low 8 bits are 00101100, which equals 44.

questions.text:
Consider the following code using DataStreams. What is the expected behavior?

DataOutputStream output = new DataOutputStream(new FileOutputStream("test.dat"));
output.writeUTF("Java");
output.writeDouble(85.5);
output.close();

DataInputStream input = new DataInputStream(new FileInputStream("test.dat"));
double score = input.readDouble();
String name = input.readUTF();

choices.label: It executes successfully and reads the score and name.
choices.text: It executes successfully and reads the score and name.

choices.label: It reads garbage data or throws an exception because the read order does not match the write order.
choices.text: It reads garbage data or throws an exception because the read order does not match the write order.

questions.explanation: Binary data must be read in the same order and format it was written. Writing a String then a Double, but reading a Double then a String, will interpret the bytes of the String as part of the Double, resulting in incorrect data or errors.

questions.text:
How can you append data to an existing binary file named 'data.dat'?

// Select the correct constructor
FileOutputStream output = ...
questions.explanation: To append data to an existing file, you must use the constructor FileOutputStream(String name, boolean append) with the append argument set to true.

questions.text:
What exception is typically used to detect the end of a file when using a DataInputStream loop?

try {
  while (true) {
    System.out.println(input.readDouble());
  }
} catch (__________ ex) {
  System.out.println("End of file reached");
}
questions.explanation: DataInputStream methods throw an EOFException when they attempt to read past the end of the file.

questions.text:
Which snippet correctly creates a buffered output stream for a file named 'out.dat'?

DataOutputStream output = ...
questions.explanation: To use buffering with DataOutputStream, you wrap the FileOutputStream in a BufferedOutputStream, and then wrap that in the DataOutputStream.

questions.text:
What is the output of the following code if 'numbers.dat' is empty initially?

try (DataOutputStream output = new DataOutputStream(new FileOutputStream("numbers.dat"))) {
  output.writeInt(1);
  output.writeLong(1);
}
// Assuming file length query:
File file = new File("numbers.dat");
System.out.println(file.length());
questions.explanation: writeInt writes 4 bytes. writeLong writes 8 bytes. Total bytes = 4 + 8 = 12.
